Quote: Excellence is never an accident. It is always the result of high intention, sincere effort, and intelligent execution.
Context: On the deliberate cultivation of virtuous character

Quote: We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence, then, is not an act, but a habit.
Context: Defining virtue as a settled state of character

Quote: The good of man is the active exercise of his soul's faculties in conformity with excellence or virtue.
Context: Defining the human good (Eudaimonia)

Quote: Virtue is a mean state between two vices, one of excess and one of deficiency.
Context: The core doctrine of the virtuous mean

Quote: Moral excellence comes about as a result of habit. We become just by doing just acts, temperate by doing temperate acts, brave by doing brave acts.
Context: On how virtue is acquired through practice

Quote: The greatest virtues are those which are most useful to others.
Context: On the social value of virtue

Quote: Patience is bitter, but its fruit is sweet.
Context: On the enduring value of virtuous struggle

Quote: The ideal man bears the accidents of life with dignity and grace, making the best of circumstances.
Context: On the character of the magnanimous man

Quote: It is not enough to know about virtue, then, but we must endeavor to possess and use it.
Context: On the practical, not just theoretical, aim of ethics

Quote: The virtue of justice consists in moderation, as regulated by wisdom.
Context: On the nature of the virtue of justice

Quote: The character which results from wealth is that of a prosperous fool.
Context: On how wealth without virtue corrupts

Quote: The end of virtue is the best and most excellent state of a thing.
Context: Connecting virtue with teleology

Quote: To run away from trouble is a form of cowardice and, while it is true that the suicide braves death, he does it not for some noble object but to escape some ill.
Context: On why suicide is not an act of courage

Quote: The brave man is not he who feels no fear, but he whose noble soul subdues its fear.
Context: Clarifying the true nature of courage

Quote: The virtues are destroyed by excess and by deficiency.
Context: The danger of straying from the mean

Quote: The greatest of virtues, and the parent of all the rest, is justice.
Context: On the paramount importance of justice

Quote: The good man is one for whom the natural goods are good.
Context: On how virtue dictates the value of external goods

Quote: The virtuous man is content to dream what the wicked man actually does.
Context: On the restrained desires of the virtuous

Quote: The beauty of the soul shines out when a man bears with composure one heavy mischance after another.
Context: On displaying virtue in times of hardship

Quote: Virtue is more clearly shown in the performance of fine actions than in the non-performance of base ones.
Context: Virtue requires positive action, not just avoidance

Quote: The man who is angry at the right things and with the right people, and, further, as he ought, when he ought, and as long as he ought, is praised.
Context: An example of virtue in the emotion of anger

Quote: The liberal man will give to the right people, the right amounts, and at the right time.
Context: On the virtue of liberality with wealth

Quote: The virtuous man, in his manner of giving and taking, will aim at the noble and avoid the base.
Context: On the noble intention behind virtuous acts

Quote: Civic virtue is that which qualifies a man to rule and be ruled in turn.
Context: On the political dimension of virtue

Quote: The ultimate value of life depends upon awareness and the power of contemplation rather than upon mere survival.
Context: Connecting virtue to the life of the mind

Quote: Happiness is the meaning and the purpose of life, the whole aim and end of human existence.
Context: Introducing Eudaimonia as the highest human good

Quote: One swallow does not make a spring, nor does one sunny day; similarly, one day or a short time does not make a man blessed and happy.
Context: On happiness requiring a complete life

Quote: Happiness is an activity of the soul in accordance with complete virtue.
Context: The formal definition of happiness

Quote: The happy life is thought to be one of excellence; now an excellent life requires exertion, and does not consist in amusement.
Context: Happiness is an active, serious pursuit

Quote: For the things we have to learn before we can do them, we learn by doing them.
Context: On how we become happy by acting virtuously

Quote: The happy man lives well and does well; for we have practically defined happiness as a sort of good life and good action.
Context: Connecting happiness to living and acting well

Quote: Happiness seems to require a modicum of external prosperity.
Context: Acknowledging the role of external circumstances

Quote: The life of money-making is one undertaken under compulsion, and wealth is evidently not the good we are seeking.
Context: Distinguishing happiness from material wealth

Quote: The best way of life, for individuals and cities alike, is the life of virtue, when virtue has external goods enough for its performance.
Context: The political condition for widespread happiness

Quote: The happy man will have the attribute of permanence, and will remain happy throughout his life.
Context: On the enduring nature of true happiness

Quote: The pleasure of contemplation is superior in its purity and enduring quality.
Context: On the highest form of happiness

Quote: No one would choose to live without friends, even if he had all other goods.
Context: On friendship as an essential component of happiness

Quote: The man who is truly good and wise will bear all kinds of fortune in a seemly way.
Context: On maintaining happiness through life's challenges

Quote: Happiness is a kind of energy of the soul.
Context: A definition from his other ethical work

Quote: The many, the most vulgar, seem to conceive the good and happiness as pleasure.
Context: Critiquing a common but shallow view of happiness

Quote: The happy man is one who expresses his complete virtue in his actions, and is sufficiently equipped with external goods.
Context: A summary of the conditions for happiness

Quote: The life of the intellect is the best and most pleasant for man, because the intellect is the highest part of him.
Context: On the superiority of the contemplative life

Quote: The good for man is an activity of the soul in accordance with virtue, and if there are multiple virtues, in accordance with the best and most complete.
Context: A refined definition of the human good

Quote: We must not listen to those who urge us to think human thoughts because we are human, or mortal thoughts because we are mortal; rather, we should become immortal and do everything to live by the best that is in us.
Context: Exhortation to pursue the highest, divine-like happiness

Quote: The man who does not rejoice in noble actions is not even good.
Context: The virtuous man takes pleasure in doing good

Quote: The happy man, living in this activity, will also be most beloved of the gods.
Context: Connecting human happiness to the divine

Quote: The political life is second only to the contemplative life in its claim to happiness.
Context: Ranking the ways of life

Quote: Happiness is a state of the soul, not a fleeting mood.
Context: Distinguishing happiness from temporary emotion

Quote: The cultivation of the understanding is the greatest blessing.
Context: On the intellectual component of happiness

Quote: To be always seeking after the useful does not become free and exalted souls.
Context: On the need for leisure and higher pursuits

Quote: Man is by nature a political animal.
Context: On the innate social and civic nature of humans

Quote: The city is prior in nature to the household and to the individual, for the whole must be prior to the part.
Context: On the primacy of the political community

Quote: The rule of law is preferable to that of any individual.
Context: Arguing for the sovereignty of law over men

Quote: Even when laws have been written down, they ought not always to remain unaltered.
Context: On the need for laws to adapt to circumstances

Quote: The best political community is formed by citizens of the middle class.
Context: On the stabilizing role of the middle class

Quote: At his best, man is the noblest of all animals; separated from law and justice he is the worst.
Context: On the role of justice in perfecting human nature

Quote: Poverty is the parent of revolution and crime.
Context: On the social dangers of extreme inequality

Quote: The state exists for the sake of the good life.
Context: The teleological purpose of the polis

Quote: He who is unable to live in society, or who has no need because he is sufficient for himself, must be either a beast or a god.
Context: Reiterating the necessity of political community

Quote: The basis of a democratic state is liberty.
Context: Identifying the core principle of democracy

Quote: It is a peculiarity of man that he alone has any sense of good and evil, of just and unjust. And it is the sharing of a common view in these matters that makes a household and a state.
Context: On shared morality as the foundation of the state

Quote: The best laws, though sanctioned by every citizen of the state, will be of no avail unless the young are trained by habit and education in the spirit of the constitution.
Context: On the importance of civic education

Quote: Tyranny is that kind of monarchy which has in view the interest of the monarch only.
Context: Defining the perverted form of monarchy

Quote: A democracy exists whenever those who are free and are not well-off form the majority and are in sovereign control of the government.
Context: A descriptive definition of democracy

Quote: The good of the state must be the end of politics, which is the highest of the practical sciences.
Context: On the noble aim of political science

Quote: Revolutionary change is not to be anticipated in a well-mixed state where the middle class is strong.
Context: On the middle class as a bulwark against revolution

Quote: The law is reason, free from passion.
Context: The ideal character of law

Quote: The political good is justice, and justice is the common advantage.
Context: Defining the goal of politics

Quote: It is not the property of the state to be a mere alliance for defense, nor to promote economic exchange.
Context: The state's purpose is more than mere utility

Quote: The best state will not make the mechanic a citizen.
Context: Reflecting the elitist view of citizenship

Quote: The city should be one, but not overly so.
Context: On the balance between unity and diversity

Quote: The legislator should direct all his military and other measures to the provision of leisure and the establishment of peace.
Context: Peace and leisure as the ultimate political aims

Quote: The virtue of a man and that of a citizen may be different.
Context: Distinguishing personal from civic virtue

Quote: A state is not a mere society, having a common place, established for the prevention of mutual crime and for the sake of exchange.
Context: Reiterating the higher purpose of the state

Quote: The end of the state is the good life, and the state is the union of families and villages in a perfect and self-sufficing life.
Context: The comprehensive definition of the state's purpose

Quote: It is the mark of an educated mind to be able to entertain a thought without accepting it.
Context: On the intellectual virtue of considering arguments

Quote: A likely impossibility is always preferable to an unconvincing possibility.
Context: A principle from his analysis of plot in tragedy

Quote: All men by nature desire to know.
Context: The opening sentence of his Metaphysics

Quote: We must, as far as possible, prove the truth of what we believe by means of argument, and if not, then it is better to assume the more probable view.
Context: On the method of dialectic

Quote: The same thing can be the object of knowledge and opinion, but not in the same respect.
Context: Distinguishing between different cognitive states

Quote: It is absurd to hold that a thing's nature is what it is when its process of generation is complete.
Context: On the importance of final cause in definition

Quote: A definition is a phrase signifying a thing's essence.
Context: A foundational concept in his logic

Quote: We think we have scientific knowledge of a thing when we know its cause.
Context: The core of his scientific method

Quote: It is not necessary to have a beard to be a philosopher, but it is necessary to have a mind that can grasp the first principles.
Context: On the intellectual requirements for philosophy

Quote: The least initial deviation from the truth is multiplied later a thousandfold.
Context: On the importance of sound first principles

Quote: To say of what is that it is not, or of what is not that it is, is false, while to say of what is that it is, and of what is not that it is not, is true.
Context: The classical correspondence theory of truth

Quote: The universal is knowable in itself, the particular is knowable by perception.
Context: On the objects of knowledge and perception

Quote: One should not require certainty from a rhetorician, nor probability from a mathematician.
Context: On the different standards of proof in different fields

Quote: The aim of argument should not be victory, but progress.
Context: On the proper goal of dialectical debate

Quote: A syllogism is a discourse in which, certain things being stated, something other than what is stated follows of necessity from their being so.
Context: The definition of a syllogism

Quote: It is the mark of a learned man to look for precision in each class of things just so far as the nature of the subject admits.
Context: On tailoring one's method to the subject matter

Quote: The more you know, the more you know you don't know.
Context: On the infinite scope of scientific inquiry

Quote: The mind is, in a way, all existing things.
Context: On the soul's capacity to know forms

Quote: We must start with what is known to us.
Context: The starting point of inquiry

Quote: A small error in the beginning leads to a great error in the end.
Context: Reiterating the importance of sound foundations

Quote: The knowledge of the opposites is one.
Context: A logical observation about related concepts

Quote: That some of our arguments are dialectical and others sophistical is clear.
Context: Distinguishing between valid and fallacious argument

Quote: The truth seems to be like the proverbial door, which no one can fail to hit.
Context: On the fundamental accessibility of truth

Quote: To perceive is to suffer.
Context: On the passive nature of sense perception

Quote: The actual knowledge of a thing is identical with its object.
Context: On the union of the knower and the known in act

Quote: In all things of nature there is something of the marvelous.
Context: On the value of studying all biological life

Quote: Nature does nothing in vain.
Context: A summary of his teleological view of the natural world

Quote: The more you know, the more you know you don't know.
Context: On the infinite scope of scientific inquiry

Quote: If one way be better than another, that you may be sure is nature's way.
Context: On the efficiency and purpose in nature

Quote: The energy of the mind is the essence of life.
Context: On the vital principle

Quote: The whole is more than the sum of its parts.
Context: On the nature of substances and their properties

Quote: It is the mark of an educated man to look for precision in each class of things just so far as the nature of the subject admits.
Context: On tailoring scientific method to the subject matter

Quote: The roots of education are bitter, but the fruit is sweet.
Context: On the enduring value of learning despite its difficulties
Reference: Diogenes LaÃ«rtius, Lives of the Philosophers

Quote: The actual knowledge of a thing is identical with its object.
Context: On the union of the knower and the known in act

Quote: The aim of art is to represent not the outward appearance of things, but their inward significance.
Context: On the philosophical value of artistic imitation

Quote: The least initial deviation from the truth is multiplied later a thousandfold.
Context: On the importance of accurate scientific principles

Quote: To understand anything, observe its beginning and its development.
Context: A principle of scientific and historical inquiry

Quote: The universe is a system of which the parts are arranged in a certain order.
Context: On the cosmos as a structured whole

Quote: The brain is an organ of minor importance, serving only to cool the blood.
Context: A reflection of his erroneous physiological theory

Quote: The form of a thing is its nature.
Context: Connecting formal cause with natural kind

Quote: The processes of nature are not random, but for a purpose.
Context: The core of Aristotelian natural philosophy

Quote: The same seeds produce either a healthy or a diseased plant, according to the condition of the soil.
Context: On the interaction of potential and environment

Quote: The eye is for the sake of seeing, not seeing for the sake of the eye.
Context: An example of final cause in biology

Quote: The stars are made of a fifth element, different from the four earthly elements.
Context: His theory of the quintessence

Quote: He who sees things grow from the beginning will have the best view of them.
Context: Reiterating the importance of studying origins

Quote: The nature of a thing is its end.
Context: A concise statement of his teleology

Quote: The mathematical sciences particularly exhibit order, symmetry, and limitation; and these are the greatest forms of the beautiful.
Context: On the aesthetic value of mathematical science

Quote: The infinite is imperfect, unfinished, and unthinkable.
Context: On the concept of the infinite in natural philosophy

Quote: Time is the number of motion in respect of before and after.
Context: His definition of time

Quote: A vacuum is impossible, because nature abhors a void.
Context: A principle that influenced medieval science

Quote: The actual is prior to the potential.
Context: A key principle in his theory of being and change

Quote: Being is said in many ways.
Context: The starting point of his analysis of being

Quote: The whole is more than the sum of its parts.
Context: On the nature of substances and their properties

Quote: The form of a thing is its essence and primary substance.
Context: On the primacy of form in defining what a thing is

Quote: The final cause, then, produces motion as being loved, but all other things move by being moved.
Context: Describing the Unmoved Mover as the final cause

Quote: God is a being whose existence is actuality, not potentiality.
Context: Describing the purely actual nature of the divine

Quote: The universe must be one and eternal.
Context: A cosmological principle

Quote: Matter is pure potentiality.
Context: Defining the nature of prime matter

Quote: The thinking part of the soul must be, in its nature, capable of receiving the form of an object.
Context: On the soul's relation to the objects of thought

Quote: The truth of a thing is in its thought.
Context: On the relation between reality and intellect

Quote: Substance is that which is neither predicable of a subject nor present in a subject.
Context: The foundational definition of primary substance

Quote: The one and the many are opposed.
Context: A basic metaphysical distinction

Quote: The eternal is more real than the perishable.
Context: On the hierarchy of being

Quote: The nature of everything is its end.
Context: A teleological view of reality

Quote: The mind itself is thinkable just as the thinkable objects are.
Context: On the mind's capacity for self-awareness

Quote: The actuality of thought is life.
Context: Connecting divine thought with the highest form of life

Quote: The principles of eternal things must be always most true.
Context: On the necessary truth of first principles

Quote: The moving cause of all things is itself unmoved.
Context: Describing the prime mover

Quote: The being of a thing is its ownness.
Context: On the unique 'what-it-is' of a substance

Quote: The infinite has no beginning, but seems to be the beginning of other things.
Context: On the problematic nature of the infinite

Quote: The form is not generated; it is the composite that comes to be.
Context: On how substantial change occurs
Reference: On Generation and Corruption, Book I

Quote: The actual is the end, and for its sake the potential is acquired.
Context: The priority of actuality in teleology

Quote: The truth is like the proverbial door, which no one can fail to hit.
Context: On the fundamental accessibility of reality to mind

Quote: The soul is the first actuality of a natural body having life potentially.
Context: The definition of the soul

Quote: The whole of a thing is that which has a beginning, a middle, and an end.
Context: A definition with metaphysical implications

Quote: The soul is, in a way, all existing things; for existing things are either perceptible or thinkable.
Context: On the soul's capacity to receive form

Quote: Hope is a waking dream.
Context: A psychological observation on the nature of hope

Quote: The energy of the mind is the essence of life.
Context: On the vital principle

Quote: To perceive is to suffer.
Context: On the passive nature of sense perception

Quote: The soul never thinks without a mental image.
Context: On the role of phantasia (imagination) in thought

Quote: The virtue of the rational soul is to be in accord with right reason.
Context: On the intellectual virtue of the soul

Quote: The desires of the irrational soul are for the pleasant.
Context: On the appetitive part of the soul

Quote: The mind is, in a way, all existing things.
Context: On the soul's capacity to know forms

Quote: The growth and nutrition of the body is the function of the vegetative soul.
Context: On the lowest faculty of the soul

Quote: The feeling of anger is a desire for retaliation.
Context: A psychological definition of anger

Quote: Fear is a pain or disturbance due to a mental picture of some destructive or painful evil in the future.
Context: A detailed psychological definition of fear

Quote: Courage is the mean state with regard to feelings of fear and confidence.
Context: Placing courage within the psychological framework of the mean

Quote: The virtue of the appetitive soul is to obey the rational soul.
Context: On the hierarchical structure of the soul

Quote: The pleasure of contemplation is superior in its purity and enduring quality.
Context: On the highest activity of the rational soul

Quote: The soul is the cause and principle of the living body.
Context: Defining the soul's relation to the body

Quote: The state of the soul is the source of our actions.
Context: On the soul as the origin of moral action

Quote: The irrational part of the soul can, in a manner, be persuaded by the rational.
Context: On the possibility of moral education

Quote: Sleep is a state of powerlessness of the perceptive faculty.
Context: A physiological and psychological observation

Quote: The memory is the persisting of the perceptive impression.
Context: His definition of memory

Quote: Youth is the age of desire.
Context: A generalization about the psychology of the young

Quote: The soul of a man is defined by his capacity for choice.
Context: Connecting the soul with prohairesis (deliberate choice)

Quote: The feeling of friendship is like the feeling of being at home.
Context: A psychological analogy for friendship

Quote: The mind is the form of forms.
Context: On the intellect's role in organizing perception

Quote: The passions are the emotions that cause men to change their opinion.
Context: On the role of emotion in rhetoric and psychology

Quote: The virtue of the theoretical intellect is wisdom, and of the practical intellect is prudence.
Context: Distinguishing the virtues of different parts of the mind

Quote: Without friends no one would choose to live, though he had all other goods.
Context: On the absolute necessity of friendship for happiness

Quote: Love is composed of a single soul inhabiting two bodies.
Context: A poetic definition of perfect friendship

Quote: Wishing to be friends is quick work, but friendship is a slow-ripening fruit.
Context: On the time and shared experience required for true friendship

Quote: Perfect friendship is the friendship of men who are good, and alike in virtue.
Context: Describing the highest form of friendship

Quote: A friend to all is a friend to none.
Context: On the impossibility of having many perfect friendships

Quote: Friendship is a thing most necessary to life, since without friends no one would choose to live, though possessed of all other advantages.
Context: Reiterating the indispensability of friendship

Quote: The desire for friendship comes quickly. Friendship does not.
Context: Distinguishing the initial impulse from the mature state

Quote: Friends hold a mirror up to each other; through that mirror they can see each other in ways that would not otherwise be accessible to them.
Context: On friendship as a source of self-awareness

Quote: It is characteristic of a friend to do good to another.
Context: The active component of friendship

Quote: The best friend is he that wishes the best for the other for the other's sake.
Context: Defining the altruistic core of friendship

Quote: Friendship seems to consist more in giving than in receiving affection.
Context: On the active nature of loving

Quote: Equality is the soul of friendship.
Context: On the importance of parity in perfect friendship

Quote: Misfortune shows those who are not really friends.
Context: On how hardship reveals the true nature of friendships

Quote: The friendship of the good is good, and it increases with their meetings.
Context: On how virtuous friendship strengthens over time

Quote: There are three kinds of friendship: friendship based on utility, on pleasure, and on goodness.
Context: The foundational taxonomy of friendships

Quote: The perfect form of friendship is that between the good, who are alike in their excellence.
Context: Reiterating the definition of the highest friendship

Quote: It is not necessary to have many friends.
Context: On the value of a few deep friendships over many shallow ones

Quote: Friendship requires more time and familiarity than mere acquaintance.
Context: On the conditions for developing friendship

Quote: The friend is another self.
Context: The famous definition of the friend

Quote: Between friends there is no need for justice, but people who are just still need the quality of friendship.
Context: On how friendship transcends mere justice

Quote: The friendship of the young seems to aim at pleasure.
Context: On the character of friendship in different stages of life

Quote: We praise those who love their friends.
Context: On the social recognition of friendship

Quote: The good man is related to his friend as to himself.
Context: Explaining the 'another self' concept

Quote: Friendship is a partnership.
Context: On the communal aspect of friendship

Quote: The friend shares his friend's sorrow and his joy.
Context: On the emotional bond between friends
