Context: On the enduring value of learning despite its difficulties
Reference: Diogenes LaÃ«rtius, Lives of the Philosophers

Quote: The educated differ from the uneducated as much as the living differ from the dead.
Context: A hyperbolic statement on the transformative power of learning

Quote: For the things we have to learn before we can do them, we learn by doing them.
Context: On the acquisition of virtues and skills through practice

Quote: It is the mark of an educated mind to be able to entertain a thought without accepting it.
Context: On the intellectual virtue of considering arguments

Quote: All men by nature desire to know.
Context: The opening sentence of his Metaphysics

Quote: The cultivation of the understanding is the greatest blessing.
Context: On the supreme value of intellectual development

Quote: Learning is not child's play; we cannot learn without pain.
Context: On the necessity of effort in education

Quote: The best way to teach morality is to make it a habit with children.
Context: On the early habituation into virtue

Quote: The one exclusive sign of thorough knowledge is the power of teaching.
Context: On teaching as the test of true understanding

Quote: Education is the best provision for old age.
Context: On the lasting benefits of a learned mind

Quote: The young are in character prone to desire and ready to carry any desire they may have formed into action.
Context: On the need to guide the impulses of the young

Quote: The aim of the wise is not to secure pleasure, but to avoid pain.
Context: A goal of practical education

Quote: We must be taught to be good.
Context: Virtue is not innate but must be learned

Quote: The best laws, though sanctioned by every citizen of the state, will be of no avail unless the young are trained by habit and education in the spirit of the constitution.
Context: On the importance of civic education

Quote: To learn is a natural pleasure, not confined to philosophers, but common to all men.
Context: On the innate human enjoyment of learning

Quote: The most perfect political community must be one where the middle class is in control.
Context: Connecting political stability to education and moderation

Quote: The virtue of the rational part is to be found in teaching, not in being taught.
Context: On the active nature of the intellectual virtues

Quote: The mind is the form of forms.
Context: On the intellect's role in organizing perception and learning

Quote: Education needs these three: natural endowment, study, and constant practice.
Context: The three components of successful learning

Quote: The wise man does not expose himself needlessly to danger, but is willing, in great crises, to give even his life.
Context: The educated know what is worth dying for

Quote: The goal of education is to make the student like and dislike what he ought.
Context: The aim of moral education is proper habituation

Quote: The educated man is one who can judge well in the things he knows.
Context: The practical application of knowledge

Quote: To be always seeking after the useful does not become free and exalted souls.
Context: On the need for liberal, not just vocational, education

Quote: The beginning of all learning is wonder.
Context: On the philosophical impulse that starts with awe

Quote: The state has a responsibility to educate its citizens.
Context: On public education as a political duty

Quote: Persuasion is achieved by the speaker's personal character when the speech is so spoken as to make us think him credible.
Context: On one of the three modes of persuasion (Ethos)

Quote: The duty of rhetoric is to deal with such matters as we deliberate upon without arts or systems to guide us.
Context: Defining the domain of rhetorical art

Quote: One should not require certainty from a rhetorician, nor probability from a mathematician.
Context: On the different standards of proof in different fields

Quote: Rhetoric is the counterpart of Dialectic.
Context: Placing rhetoric within the broader field of logic and argument

Quote: The fool tells me his reasons; the wise man persuades me with my own.
Context: On effective persuasion aligning with the audience's views

Quote: The persuasive is persuasive to someone.
Context: Persuasion is context and audience-dependent

Quote: It is not enough to know what to say; one must also know how to say it.
Context: On the importance of delivery and style

Quote: The emotional state of the audience is a key factor in persuasion.
Context: On one of the three modes of persuasion (Pathos)

Quote: The example is a rhetorical induction.
Context: On the use of examples as a form of proof

Quote: The enthymeme is a rhetorical syllogism.
Context: On the primary tool of logical proof in rhetoric

Quote: The most important aspect of style is clarity.
Context: A fundamental principle of effective communication

Quote: To understand the emotions is to understand the human soul.
Context: On the deep connection between rhetoric and psychology

Quote: The role of the speaker is to see the available means of persuasion in each case.
Context: The core task of the orator

Quote: The hearer must be in a friendly mood toward the speaker.
Context: On the importance of the audience's disposition

Quote: The proof from the opposite is a common topic.
Context: On a specific rhetorical strategy

Quote: The epideictic speech is concerned with praise or blame.
Context: Defining one of the three genres of oratory

Quote: The deliberative speech is concerned with the future.
Context: Defining the genre of political oratory

Quote: The forensic speech is concerned with the past.
Context: Defining the genre of legal oratory

Quote: The use of maxims is appropriate for older speakers.
Context: On the stylistic use of proverbial statements

Quote: The arousing of prejudice, pity, anger, and similar emotions has nothing to do with the essential facts.
Context: A critique of appeals that bypass logic

Quote: The style should be appropriate to the subject, the audience, and the speaker.
Context: The principle of decorum in rhetoric

Quote: The metaphor is the mark of genius.
Context: On the highest form of stylistic excellence

Quote: The command of metaphor is the greatest thing by far.
Context: Reinforcing the importance of metaphorical thinking

Quote: The purpose of rhetoric is not to persuade but to see the available means of persuasion.
Context: Defining rhetoric as an art of analysis, not manipulation

Quote: The truth itself is always a stronger argument than its copy.
Context: On the inherent persuasive power of truth

Quote: The aim of art is to represent not the outward appearance of things, but their inward significance.
Context: On the philosophical value of artistic imitation

Quote: Poetry is more philosophical and more serious than history.
Context: On poetry's concern with universal truths, not specific events

Quote: A tragedy is the imitation of an action that is serious and complete.
Context: The definition of tragedy

Quote: The plot is the soul of tragedy.
Context: On the primacy of plot (mythos) over character

Quote: Tragedy, through pity and fear, effects the proper purgation of these emotions.
Context: The famous definition of catharsis

Quote: The poet, being an imitator, must necessarily imitate one of three objects: things as they were or are, things as they are said or thought to be, or things as they ought to be.
Context: On the possible subjects of poetic representation

Quote: The whole of a thing is that which has a beginning, a middle, and an end.
Context: A key principle of poetic composition

Quote: The metaphor is the mark of genius.
Context: On the highest form of stylistic excellence

Quote: A likely impossibility is always preferable to an unconvincing possibility.
Context: A principle for constructing a believable plot

Quote: The poet's function is to describe, not the thing that has happened, but the kind of thing that might happen.
Context: Reiterating the universal nature of poetry

Quote: The perfection of style is to be clear without being mean.
Context: On the ideal quality of poetic language

Quote: The surprise arising from peripeteia is the most powerful element of tragic plot.
Context: On the dramatic power of reversal of fortune

Quote: The recognition scene is a change from ignorance to knowledge.
Context: Defining anagnorisis, a key plot device

Quote: The tragic hero is a man who is not eminently good and just, yet whose misfortune is brought about not by vice or depravity, but by some error or frailty.
Context: The definition of the tragic hero (hamartia)

Quote: The chorus should be regarded as one of the actors.
Context: On the role of the chorus in tragedy

Quote: The art of music has the power to form character.
Context: On the ethical effect of music

Quote: The objects of imitation in poetry are men in action.
Context: The fundamental subject matter of poetry

Quote: The epic and the tragic are both forms of imitation in verse.
Context: Comparing two major poetic genres

Quote: The difference between the historian and the poet is that one tells what happened and the other what might happen.
Context: Reiterating the distinction between poetry and history

Quote: The spectacle, though appealing, is the least artistic of all the parts of tragedy.
Context: De-emphasizing stage effects in favor of plot and character

Quote: The unity of plot does not consist in having one man as its subject.
Context: Clarifying the principle of unity of action

Quote: The poet must be a maker of plots rather than of verses.
Context: Reinforcing the primacy of plot construction

Quote: The art of imitation is natural to man from childhood.
Context: On the innate human drive for mimesis

Quote: The pleasure derived from imitation is a pleasure in learning.
Context: On the cognitive pleasure we get from art

Quote: The end of the art of poetry is to produce pleasure of a certain kind.
Context: On the specific pleasure proper to tragedy

Quote: Justice is the loveliest and health is the best; but the sweetest to obtain is the heart's desire.
Context: A poetic reflection on fundamental goods

Quote: At his best, man is the noblest of all animals; separated from law and justice he is the worst.
Context: On the role of justice in perfecting human nature

Quote: The rule of law is preferable to that of any individual.
Context: Arguing for the sovereignty of law over men

Quote: The law is reason, free from passion.
Context: The ideal character of law

Quote: The political good is justice, and justice is the common advantage.
Context: Defining the goal of politics and law

Quote: The greatest of virtues, and the parent of all the rest, is justice.
Context: On the paramount importance of justice

Quote: Justice is the virtue through which everybody enjoys his own possessions in accordance with the law.
Context: A definition of particular justice

Quote: The just is the lawful and the fair.
Context: The general definition of justice

Quote: The unjust man is greedy.
Context: Describing the character of the unjust person

Quote: Equity is a correction of legal justice.
Context: On the role of equity in mitigating strict law

Quote: It is in justice that the ordering of society is centered.
Context: Justice as the foundational virtue for community

Quote: The judge is intended to be a living embodiment of justice.
Context: On the role of the judge in the legal system

Quote: The man who is apt to commit injustice is the man who is apt to claim more than his share.
Context: On the nature of particular injustice

Quote: The forms of government which are based on the common interest are correct constitutions.
Context: Linking just rule to the common good

Quote: The state exists for the sake of a good life, and not for life only.
Context: The ultimate purpose of the just state

Quote: The end of law is the good of the community.
Context: The teleological purpose of law

Quote: The worst form of inequality is to try to make unequal things equal.
Context: A critique of a misguided notion of equality

Quote: The virtue of justice consists in moderation, as regulated by wisdom.
Context: Placing justice within the framework of the mean

Quote: The law has no power to command obedience except that of habit.
Context: On the importance of customary acceptance of law

Quote: The administration of justice is the principle of order in political society.
Context: Justice as the organizing force of the state

Quote: The man who is isolated from law and justice is the most unholy and the most savage of animals.
Context: Reiterating the civilizing power of justice

Quote: The equitable man is one who does not insist on his rights to the full, but is content to receive a little less.
Context: Describing the character of the equitable person

Quote: The general form of justice is complete virtue in relation to others.
Context: Defining universal justice

Quote: The laws must be laid down in general terms, but actions are concerned with particulars.
Context: Explaining the inherent limitation of written law

Quote: The just man will need to use his mind to discern what is fair in each situation.
Context: On the practical wisdom required for justice

Quote: Courage is the first of human qualities because it is the quality which guarantees the others.
Context: On the foundational role of courage in enabling virtue

Quote: The brave man is not he who feels no fear, but he whose noble soul subdues its fear.
Context: Clarifying the true nature of courage

Quote: Courage is the mean state with regard to feelings of fear and confidence.
Context: Placing courage within the psychological framework of the mean

Quote: The coward calls the brave man rash, the rash man calls him a coward.
Context: On how one's own character colors their perception of others

Quote: The brave man faces fearful things as he ought and as reason directs, for the sake of the noble.
Context: The motive and standard for courageous action

Quote: To run away from trouble is a form of cowardice and, while it is true that the suicide braves death, he does it not for some noble object but to escape some ill.
Context: On why suicide is not an act of courage

Quote: The courage of a man is shown in commanding, of a woman in obeying.
Context: Gendering the application of the virtue of courage

Quote: Perfect courage is to do without witnesses what one would be capable of doing before the whole world.
Context: On the importance of internal virtue

Quote: The brave man is full of confidence before terrors, and of fear only in the right way.
Context: Describing the emotional state of the courageous

Quote: The coward is a despairing sort of person; for he fears everything.
Context: Describing the character of the coward

Quote: The rash man is a boaster and a pretender to courage.
Context: Describing the character of the rash person

Quote: The brave man is unconquerable.
Context: On the resilience of the courageous character

Quote: Courage is not about the absence of fear, but the triumph over it.
Context: A popular interpretation of his view on fear

Quote: The man who endures and fears the right things, for the right purpose, in the right manner, and at the right time, is brave.
Context: A comprehensive definition of the courageous act

Quote: The greatest courage is to be able to bear the changes of fortune with equanimity.
Context: On courage in the face of life's vicissitudes

Quote: Fear is a pain or disturbance due to a mental picture of some destructive or painful evil in the future.
Context: A detailed psychological definition of fear

Quote: The feeling of confidence is the opposite of fear.
Context: Defining confidence in relation to fear

Quote: The coward is one who is excessive in fear.
Context: Placing cowardice as a vice of excess

Quote: The brave man's actions are motivated by the noble, the rash man's by the desire for honor.
Context: Distinguishing true courage from its imitation

Quote: Courage is the knowledge of what is truly to be feared.
Context: Connecting courage with practical wisdom

Quote: The man who is fearless in facing a noble death is truly brave.
Context: On the ultimate test of courage

Quote: The courage of the citizen-soldier is inspired by the law and the fear of disgrace.
Context: On political courage versus pure virtue

Quote: The brave man, in daring, dares the right things.
Context: The quality of the courageous act

Quote: Fear makes men deliberate.
Context: On the psychological effect of fear

Quote: The courageous man is both fearful and confident, but in the right things and in the right way.
Context: Summarizing the mean state of courage

Quote: Wealth is evidently not the good we are seeking; for it is merely useful and for the sake of something else.
Context: Distinguishing between instrumental and final goods

Quote: The life of money-making is one undertaken under compulsion, and wealth is evidently not the good we are seeking.
Context: Distinguishing happiness from material wealth

Quote: The greatest crimes are committed not for the sake of necessities, but for the sake of superfluities.
Context: On the dangers of pursuing wealth beyond need

Quote: The character which results from wealth is that of a prosperous fool.
Context: On how wealth without virtue corrupts

Quote: The liberal man will give to the right people, the right amounts, and at the right time.
Context: On the virtue of liberality with wealth

Quote: Poverty is the parent of revolution and crime.
Context: On the social dangers of extreme inequality

Quote: The art of wealth-getting is necessary, but not natural.
Context: Distinguishing between natural and unnatural economics

Quote: The true form of wealth-getting is the management of the household.
Context: Defining the scope of 'economics'

Quote: Riches are a good, for they are an instrument of virtue.
Context: Acknowledging the instrumental value of wealth

Quote: The avaricious man is one who is excessive in his desire for wealth.
Context: Defining the vice related to wealth

Quote: The prodigal man ruins himself, which is foolish.
Context: Defining the vice of wastefulness

Quote: Wealth is a tool for living well, not the end of life.
Context: Reiterating the instrumental nature of wealth

Quote: The best political community is formed by citizens of the middle class.
Context: On the economic basis of political stability

Quote: The use of money was invented to facilitate exchange.
Context: On the origin and purpose of currency

Quote: The unnatural form of wealth-getting is usury, which is most reasonably hated.
Context: His condemnation of lending money at interest

Quote: The liberal man does not value wealth for its own sake.
Context: The attitude of the virtuous toward money

Quote: The wealth of a nation consists not in its money, but in the productivity of its land and people.
Context: A view of real wealth

Quote: To be rich is to have a sufficiency of the instruments of life and of the good life.
Context: A definition of being truly 'rich'

Quote: The desire for wealth is limitless.
Context: On the potentially infinite nature of material desire

Quote: The illiberal man is pained both when he spends and when he receives nothing.
Context: Describing the misery of the stingy person

Quote: Wealth is not the good, but it is a good.
Context: A nuanced assessment of wealth's value

Quote: The possession of a moderate amount of wealth is an advantage for virtue.
Context: On the usefulness of moderate means

Quote: The greatest injustices are committed for the sake of excessive possessions.
Context: Linking injustice to greed

Quote: The art of exchange is not natural to man.
Context: On the derivative nature of trade

Quote: The purpose of the household is to secure the necessities of life.
Context: The fundamental economic unit

Quote: Virtue is the golden mean between two vices, the one of excess and the other of deficiency.
Context: The core doctrine of the virtuous mean

Quote: Anybody can become angry â that is easy, but to be angry with the right person and to the right degree and at the right time and for the right purpose, and in the right way â that is not within everybody's power and is not easy.
Context: An example of finding the mean in the emotion of anger

Quote: The virtues are destroyed by excess and by deficiency.
Context: The danger of straying from the mean

Quote: Courage is the mean state with regard to feelings of fear and confidence.
Context: Placing courage within the framework of the mean

Quote: The liberal man will give to the right people, the right amounts, and at the right time.
Context: On the virtue of liberality as a mean

Quote: The man who is angry at the right things and with the right people, and, further, as he ought, when he ought, and as long as he ought, is praised.
Context: Another example of the mean in emotions

Quote: The mean is hard to attain, and is grasped by perception, not by reasoning.
Context: On the situational nature of finding the mean

Quote: The best life is the life of the mean, the life of moderation.
Context: The mean as the guiding principle for the good life

Quote: The vices respectively fall short of or exceed what is right in both passions and actions.
Context: Defining vice in relation to the mean

Quote: The mean state is in a sense an extreme, for it is the best and the peak of excellence.
Context: The mean is not mediocrity but perfection

Quote: The task of ethics is to determine the mean.
Context: The central project of his ethical theory

Quote: The mean is relative to us, not to the thing itself.
Context: The mean is not an absolute number but depends on the person and situation

Quote: The man who runs away from everything in fear is a coward; the man who fears nothing is rash.
Context: Illustrating the vices of excess and deficiency for courage

Quote: The prodigal man exceeds in giving and is deficient in taking; the avaricious man is deficient in giving and exceeds in taking.
Context: Applying the doctrine to the use of wealth

Quote: The virtue of justice consists in moderation, as regulated by wisdom.
Context: Placing justice within the framework of the mean

Quote: The mean state in pleasures and pains is temperance.
Context: Defining the virtue of temperance as a mean

Quote: The intemperate man is led on by pleasure, the insensible man is deficient in the enjoyment of pleasure.
Context: The vices related to temperance

Quote: The best political community is formed by citizens of the middle class.
Context: Applying the doctrine of the mean to politics

Quote: The mean is what is neither excessive nor deficient.
Context: A simple definition of the mean

Quote: To hit the mean is hard, and to err is easy.
Context: On the challenge of virtuous action

Quote: The good man, in his manner of giving and taking, will aim at the noble and avoid the base.
Context: The motive behind aiming for the mean

Quote: The mean state is praised and is successful, while the extremes are neither right nor praised.
Context: The practical and ethical superiority of the mean

Quote: The virtue of the rational soul is to be in accord with right reason, which is the mean.
Context: Connecting reason with the discovery of the mean

Quote: The mean is determined by the person of practical wisdom.
Context: The role of the phronimos (practically wise person)

Quote: The life in accordance with the mean is the life of happiness.
Context: Connecting the mean to the ultimate human good

Quote: Nature does nothing in vain.
Context: A summary of his teleological view of the natural world

Quote: What is the end of human life? It is happiness. But what is happiness? It is the actualization of the soul's potential in accordance with virtue.
Context: Connecting his teleology with his ethical theory

Quote: The final cause, then, produces motion as being loved, but all other things move by being moved.
Context: Describing the Unmoved Mover as the final cause of all motion

Quote: The eye is for the sake of seeing, not seeing for the sake of the eye.
Context: An example of final cause in biology

Quote: The state exists for the sake of the good life.
Context: The teleological purpose of the polis

Quote: The nature of a thing is its end.
Context: A concise statement of his teleology

Quote: We do not understand a thing until we have grasped its 'why,' that is to say, its cause.
Context: The importance of final cause for scientific understanding

Quote: The processes of nature are not random, but for a purpose.
Context: The core of Aristotelian natural philosophy

Quote: The actual is the end, and for its sake the potential is acquired.
Context: The priority of actuality in teleology

Quote: The good is that at which all things aim.
Context: The teleological starting point of his ethics

Quote: The form of a thing is its purpose and its end.
Context: Connecting formal and final cause

Quote: The final cause is the best of all causes, for it is the cause of causes.
Context: Elevating the final cause above the others

Quote: The city is prior in nature to the individual, for the whole must be prior to the part.
Context: The teleological priority of the community

Quote: The end of law is the good of the community.
Context: The teleological purpose of law

Quote: The purpose of the art of medicine is health.
Context: An example of teleology in the arts

Quote: The soul is the cause and principle of the living body.
Context: The soul as the final cause of the body's organization

Quote: The virtue of a thing is relative to its proper work.
Context: Connecting virtue with the telos of a thing

Quote: The ultimate end of human life is contemplation.
Context: The highest purpose for a human being

Quote: The final cause is the 'for the sake of which.'
Context: A simple definition of the final cause

Quote: The state is a creation of nature, and man is by nature a political animal.
Context: The teleological origin and purpose of the state

Quote: The purpose of rhetoric is not to persuade but to see the available means of persuasion.
Context: The proper end of the art of rhetoric

Quote: The aim of art is to represent not the outward appearance of things, but their inward significance.
Context: The final cause of artistic imitation

Quote: The end of the state is the good life, and the state is the union of families and villages in a perfect and self-sufficing life.
Context: The comprehensive definition of the state's purpose

Quote: The function of man is the active exercise of the soul's faculties in conformity with reason.
Context: The ergon (function) argument for human telos

Quote: The final cause is the logos, the account of what it is to be a thing.
Context: Identifying the final cause with the formal cause in definition

Quote: The female is, as it were, a mutilated male.
Context: A reflection of his biological and sociological views on gender

Quote: Silence is a woman's glory.
Context: On the expected social conduct of women in the household

Quote: The man is by nature superior and the governing party; the female is the inferior and subject.
Context: Justifying patriarchal hierarchy within the household

Quote: A woman's virtue is to be pretty and to work hard.
Context: Defining female virtue in terms of appearance and domestic duty

Quote: The courage of a man is shown in commanding, of a woman in obeying.
Context: Gendering the application of the virtue of courage

Quote: The relation of male to female is by nature a relation of superior to inferior and ruler to ruled.
Context: A foundational statement of his view on gender hierarchy

Quote: A woman is an unfinished man, left standing on a lower step in the scale of development.
Context: A metaphorical expression of his biological view

Quote: The female provides the material, the male provides the form and principle of movement for the generated entity.
Context: His theory of reproduction, assigning a passive role to the female

Quote: The deliberative faculty in a woman is without authority.
Context: On the supposed lack of full rational capacity in women

Quote: It is fitting for a woman to be a good housekeeper, and to keep what is brought into the house.
Context: Defining the domestic role of a wife

Quote: The virtue of a woman and a man is not the same; a man's virtue lies in commanding, a woman's in obeying.
Context: A direct statement on the gendered nature of virtue

Quote: A woman's body is softer than a man's, and her soul more susceptible to fear and compassion.
Context: A physiological and psychological generalization

Quote: The woman is like a fertile field, the man like the sower of the seed.
Context: An agricultural analogy for his theory of reproduction

Quote: The friendship between husband and wife is the same as that which exists between ruler and subject.
Context: Placing marital relations within a political framework

Quote: Women should be seen, not heard.
Context: A popular summary of his view on female conduct

Quote: The woman is part of the property of the man.
Context: Reflecting the legal status of women in his time

Quote: A good wife should be the mistress of her home, having under her care all that is within it.
Context: The prescribed domain of female authority

Quote: The female condition is a natural deformity.
Context: A harsh biological conclusion from his theory

Quote: In the association of man and wife, the man rules by virtue of his superior merit.
Context: The justification for male rule in the household

Quote: The courage of a woman is shown not in action but in endurance.
Context: A gendered definition of courage

Quote: The woman's role is to preserve what the man acquires.
Context: The division of economic labor within the household

Quote: A modest silence is a woman's crown.
Context: On the virtue of female silence

Quote: The female is weaker and colder by nature.
Context: A physiological claim about female constitution

Quote: The wife is to the husband as the body is to the soul.
Context: An analogy for the hierarchical union of marriage

Quote: The best women are those who are least spoken of among men.
Context: On the ideal of female anonymity

Quote: The man is the ruler of the wife, as the statesman is the ruler of the citizens.
Context: Analogizing the husband-wife relationship to political rule

Quote: A man is a coupling of the master and the slave: the soul ruling the body is master, the intellect ruling the appetite is a statesman and king.
Context: Describing the hierarchical nature of the ideal male soul

Quote: The man who is isolated, who is unable to share in the benefits of political association, or has no need to share because he is already self-sufficient, is no part of the city, and must therefore be either a beast or a god.
Context: On the essential political nature of man

Quote: The man who is truly good and wise will bear all kinds of fortune in a seemly way, and will always act in the noblest manner that the circumstances allow.
Context: On the ideal character of a virtuous man

Quote: It is not necessary to have a beard to be a philosopher, but it is necessary to have a mind that can grasp the first principles.
Context: On the intellectual, not physical, requirements for philosophy

Quote: The courage of a man is shown in commanding.
Context: The masculine expression of the virtue of courage

Quote: A man is the origin of action, the begetter of change.
Context: Associating masculinity with agency and initiation

Quote: The virtue of a man is to be able to rule.
Context: Defining male virtue in terms of leadership

Quote: The man who is happy in solitude is either a beast or a god.
Context: Reiterating the social nature of man

Quote: The man of practical wisdom is the one who can deliberate well about what is good and advantageous for himself.
Context: The ideal of male rationality

Quote: The magnanimous man is concerned with honors and dishonors.
Context: Describing the 'great-souled' man

Quote: The man who is his own master is free.
Context: On the ideal of self-governance

Quote: The man who is unable to live in society must be either a beast or a god.
Context: The famous dictum on human sociality

Quote: The man of perfect virtue is the measure of what is noble and just.
Context: The phronimos as the standard for ethical judgment

Quote: The man who shuns and fears everything and stands up to nothing becomes a coward.
Context: The path to the vice of cowardice

Quote: The man who does not need others is either a beast or a god.
Context: On the necessity of friendship and community

Quote: The man who is by nature not his own but another's is by nature a slave.
Context: Defining the 'natural slave'

Quote: The man who is to be a good ruler must first have been ruled.
Context: The importance of experience for leadership

Quote: The man who is incontinent acts from desire, not from choice.
Context: Distinguishing weakness of will from vice

Quote: The man who is his own best friend is the one who most enjoys his own company.
Context: On the virtuous man's relationship with himself

Quote: The man who is without a city-state is either a poor sort of being, or a being higher than man.
Context: Reiterating the political nature of man

Quote: The man who is to be a good citizen must have the virtue of the good man.
Context: The ideal of the virtuous citizen

Quote: The man who is serious about the soul ruins the body, and he who is serious about the body ruins the soul.
Context: On the need for balance in life

Quote: The man who is to be a good ruler must have been a good subject.
Context: The path to leadership through obedience

Quote: The man who is self-sufficient is the one who needs nothing from others.
Context: An ideal rarely, if ever, attained

Quote: Love is composed of a single soul inhabiting two bodies.
Context: A poetic definition of perfect friendship or love

Quote: To love is to wish for the good of the other for the other's sake.
Context: Defining love as disinterested goodwill

Quote: Friendship is a slow-ripening fruit.
Context: On the time and shared experience required for deep bonds

Quote: Perfect friendship is the friendship of men who are good, and alike in virtue; for these wish well alike to each other insofar as they are good, and they are good in themselves.
Context: Describing the highest form of friendship

Quote: Desire is a kind of pain.
Context: On the psychology of wanting something one does not have

Quote: For though we love both the truth and our friends, piety requires us to honor the truth first.
Context: On the ultimate commitment of the philosopher

Quote: Love is the cause of unity in all things.
Context: The cosmic role of love (Eros) as a final cause

Quote: The friend is another self.
Context: The famous definition of the friend

Quote: The desire for friendship comes quickly. Friendship does not.
Context: Distinguishing the initial impulse from the mature state

Quote: To perceive is to suffer.
Context: On the passive nature of sense perception, related to desire

Quote: The final cause, then, produces motion as being loved.
Context: The Unmoved Mover as the object of universal desire

Quote: The feeling of friendship is like the feeling of being at home.
Context: A psychological analogy for the comfort of love

Quote: The object of love is the beautiful.
Context: A simple definition of what attracts love

Quote: The greatest of all pleasures is the pleasure of love.
Context: Acknowledging the power of love's pleasure

Quote: The desire for the good is the object of all rational wish.
Context: Love in its rational form aims at the good

Quote: The friend shares his friend's sorrow and his joy.
Context: On the emotional bond of love and friendship

Quote: The love of a mother is the most disinterested of all loves.
Context: An observation on maternal love

Quote: The desire for the beautiful is innate in the human soul.
Context: On the natural human attraction to beauty

Quote: The object of erotic love is the beautiful, not the good.
Context: Distinguishing different kinds of love

Quote: The pleasure of contemplation is superior in its purity and enduring quality.
Context: The highest form of love is the love of knowing

Quote: The love of the divine is the highest form of love.
Context: The ultimate object of philosophical love

Quote: The desire for knowledge is the desire for the form of the object.
Context: Intellectual love as the desire for understanding

Quote: The friend is the greatest of external goods.
Context: The supreme importance of loving relationships

Quote: The state of being in love is a kind of excess of feeling.
Context: A psychological observation on the intensity of love

Quote: The love between unequals is based on utility or pleasure.
Context: On the inferior forms of friendship and love

Quote: God is a being whose existence is actuality, not potentiality.
Context: Describing the purely actual and perfect nature of the divine

Quote: The final cause, then, produces motion as being loved, but all other things move by being moved.
Context: Describing the Unmoved Mover as the final cause

Quote: The life of God is a life of perfect contemplation.
Context: The activity of the divine mind

Quote: God is thought thinking thought itself.
Context: The famous description of divine activity

Quote: The universe must be one and eternal, and the prime mover must be one and eternal.
Context: A cosmological argument for a single, eternal god

Quote: The divine is the first and highest principle.
Context: The foundational role of the divine in metaphysics

Quote: God is not a ruler in the sense of issuing commands, but as an end which moves by being loved.
Context: The non-providential, final-causal role of God

Quote: The happy man, living in this activity, will also be most beloved of the gods.
Context: Connecting human happiness to the divine

Quote: The divine is indivisible and without parts.
Context: On the simplicity of the divine nature

Quote: The first mover is eternal and without magnitude.
Context: Arguing for the immateriality of God

Quote: God is always in that good state in which we sometimes are.
Context: Contrasting perfect divine activity with intermittent human activity

Quote: The activity of God is immortality, that is, eternal life.
Context: The divine life is eternal actuality

Quote: The principle and first of beings is immovable.
Context: The Unmoved Mover is the foundation of all motion

Quote: The divine thought is the most excellent of things.
Context: The supreme value of the divine intellect

Quote: God does not will the universe; the universe wills God.
Context: The universe is drawn toward God as its final cause

Quote: The prime mover exists of necessity, and inasmuch as it exists by necessity, its mode of being is good.
Context: The necessary and good existence of God

Quote: The divine is that for the sake of which wisdom is sought.
Context: The ultimate object of philosophical inquiry

Quote: The stars are divine and eternal beings.
Context: His view of the celestial bodies as divine entities

Quote: The love of God is the cause of the motion of the spheres.
Context: How the final cause operates cosmologically

Quote: God is a living being, eternal, most good.
Context: A summary of the divine attributes

Quote: The mind of God is the home of forms.
Context: A Platonic residue in his thought

Quote: The divine is not jealous.
Context: Contrasting the Greek concept of jealous gods with his philosophical God

Quote: The activity of the divine is pure bliss.
Context: The emotional state of the divine life

Quote: The first principle must be the most powerful of all causes.
Context: The supreme causal efficacy of the divine

Quote: To know the divine is the highest human endeavor.
Context: The ultimate purpose of philosophy and human life

Quote: The good of man is the active exercise of his soul's faculties in conformity with excellence or virtue.
Context: Defining the human good (Eudaimonia)

Quote: The greatest virtues are those which are most useful to others.
Context: On the social value of virtue

Quote: It is not enough to know about virtue, then, but we must endeavor to possess and use it.
Context: On the practical, not just theoretical, aim of ethics

Quote: The end of virtue is the best and most excellent state of a thing.
Context: Connecting virtue with teleology

Quote: The virtuous man is content to dream what the wicked man actually does.
Context: On the restrained desires of the virtuous

Quote: The happy life is thought to be one of excellence; now an excellent life requires exertion, and does not consist in amusement.
Context: Happiness is an active, serious pursuit

Quote: The happy man, living in this activity, will also be most beloved of the gods.
Context: Connecting human happiness to the divine

Quote: The political life is second only to the contemplative life in its claim to happiness.
Context: Ranking the ways of life

Quote: Happiness is a state of the soul, not a fleeting mood.
Context: Distinguishing happiness from temporary emotion

Quote: To be always seeking after the useful does not become free and exalted souls.
Context: On the need for leisure and higher pursuits

Quote: The best political community is formed by citizens of the middle class.
Context: On the stabilizing role of the middle class

Quote: Tyranny is that kind of monarchy which has in view the interest of the monarch only.
Context: Defining the perverted form of monarchy

Quote: A democracy exists whenever those who are free and are not well-off form the majority and are in sovereign control of the government.
Context: A descriptive definition of democracy

Quote: The good of the state must be the end of politics, which is the highest of the practical sciences.
Context: On the noble aim of political science

Quote: Revolutionary change is not to be anticipated in a well-mixed state where the middle class is strong.
Context: On the middle class as a bulwark against revolution

Quote: All men by nature desire to know.
Context: The opening sentence of his Metaphysics

Quote: We must, as far as possible, prove the truth of what we believe by means of argument, and if not, then it is better to assume the more probable view.
Context: On the method of dialectic

Quote: The same thing can be the object of knowledge and opinion, but not in the same respect.
Context: Distinguishing between different cognitive states

Quote: It is absurd to hold that a thing's nature is what it is when its process of generation is complete.
Context: On the importance of final cause in definition

Quote: A definition is a phrase signifying a thing's essence.
Context: A foundational concept in his logic

Quote: If one way be better than another, that you may be sure is nature's way.
Context: On the efficiency and purpose in nature

Quote: The energy of the mind is the essence of life.
Context: On the vital principle

Quote: It is the mark of an educated man to look for precision in each class of things just so far as the nature of the subject admits.
Context: On tailoring scientific method to the subject matter

Quote: The actual knowledge of a thing is identical with its object.
Context: On the union of the knower and the known in act

Quote: The aim of art is to represent not the outward appearance of things, but their inward significance.
Context: On the philosophical value of artistic imitation

Quote: Being is said in many ways.
Context: The starting point of his analysis of being

Quote: The form of a thing is its essence and primary substance.
Context: On the primacy of form in defining what a thing is

Quote: The universe must be one and eternal.
Context: A cosmological principle

Quote: Matter is pure potentiality.
Context: Defining the nature of prime matter

Quote: The thinking part of the soul must be, in its nature, capable of receiving the form of an object.
Context: On the soul's relation to the objects of thought

Quote: The virtue of the rational soul is to be in accord with right reason.
Context: On the intellectual virtue of the soul

Quote: The desires of the irrational soul are for the pleasant.
Context: On the appetitive part of the soul

Quote: The mind is, in a way, all existing things.
Context: On the soul's capacity to know forms

Quote: The growth and nutrition of the body is the function of the vegetative soul.
Context: On the lowest faculty of the soul

Quote: The feeling of anger is a desire for retaliation.
Context: A psychological definition of anger

Quote: A friend to all is a friend to none.
Context: On the impossibility of having many perfect friendships

Quote: Friendship is a thing most necessary to life, since without friends no one would choose to live, though possessed of all other advantages.
Context: Reiterating the indispensability of friendship

Quote: The desire for friendship comes quickly. Friendship does not.
Context: Distinguishing the initial impulse from the mature state

Quote: Friends hold a mirror up to each other; through that mirror they can see each other in ways that would not otherwise be accessible to them.
Context: On friendship as a source of self-awareness

Quote: It is characteristic of a friend to do good to another.
Context: The active component of friendship

Quote: Learning is not child's play; we cannot learn without pain.
Context: On the necessity of effort in education

Quote: The best way to teach morality is to make it a habit with children.
Context: On the early habituation into virtue

Quote: The one exclusive sign of thorough knowledge is the power of teaching.
Context: On teaching as the test of true understanding

Quote: Education is the best provision for old age.
Context: On the lasting benefits of a learned mind

Quote: The young are in character prone to desire and ready to carry any desire they may have formed into action.
Context: On the need to guide the impulses of the young

Quote: The fool tells me his reasons; the wise man persuades me with my own.
Context: On effective persuasion aligning with the audience's views

Quote: The persuasive is persuasive to someone.
Context: Persuasion is context and audience-dependent

Quote: It is not enough to know what to say; one must also know how to say it.
Context: On the importance of delivery and style

Quote: The emotional state of the audience is a key factor in persuasion.
Context: On one of the three modes of persuasion (Pathos)

Quote: The example is a rhetorical induction.
Context: On the use of examples as a form of proof

Quote: A tragedy is the imitation of an action that is serious and complete.
Context: The definition of tragedy

Quote: The plot is the soul of tragedy.
Context: On the primacy of plot (mythos) over character

Quote: Tragedy, through pity and fear, effects the proper purgation of these emotions.
Context: The famous definition of catharsis

Quote: The poet, being an imitator, must necessarily imitate one of three objects: things as they were or are, things as they are said or thought to be, or things as they ought to be.
Context: On the possible subjects of poetic representation

Quote: The whole of a thing is that which has a beginning, a middle, and an end.
Context: A key principle of poetic composition

Quote: The unjust man is greedy.
Context: Describing the character of the unjust person

Quote: Equity is a correction of legal justice.
Context: On the role of equity in mitigating strict law

Quote: It is in justice that the ordering of society is centered.
Context: Justice as the foundational virtue for community

Quote: The judge is intended to be a living embodiment of justice.
Context: On the role of the judge in the legal system

Quote: The man who is apt to commit injustice is the man who is apt to claim more than his share.
Context: On the nature of particular injustice

Quote: The coward is a despairing sort of person; for he fears everything.
Context: Describing the character of the coward

Quote: The rash man is a boaster and a pretender to courage.
Context: Describing the character of the rash person

Quote: The brave man is unconquerable.
Context: On the resilience of the courageous character

Quote: Courage is not about the absence of fear, but the triumph over it.
Context: A popular interpretation of his view on fear

Quote: The man who endures and fears the right things, for the right purpose, in the right manner, and at the right time, is brave.
Context: A comprehensive definition of the courageous act

Quote: The art of wealth-getting is necessary, but not natural.
Context: Distinguishing between natural and unnatural economics

Quote: The true form of wealth-getting is the management of the household.
Context: Defining the scope of 'economics'

Quote: Riches are a good, for they are an instrument of virtue.
Context: Acknowledging the instrumental value of wealth

Quote: The avaricious man is one who is excessive in his desire for wealth.
Context: Defining the vice related to wealth

Quote: The prodigal man ruins himself, which is foolish.
Context: Defining the vice of wastefulness

Quote: The virtues are destroyed by excess and by deficiency.
Context: The danger of straying from the mean

Quote: Courage is the mean state with regard to feelings of fear and confidence.
Context: Placing courage within the framework of the mean

Quote: The liberal man will give to the right people, the right amounts, and at the right time.
Context: On the virtue of liberality as a mean

Quote: The man who is angry at the right things and with the right people, and, further, as he ought, when he ought, and as long as he ought, is praised.
Context: Another example of the mean in emotions

Quote: The mean is hard to attain, and is grasped by perception, not by reasoning.
Context: On the situational nature of finding the mean

Quote: The eye is for the sake of seeing, not seeing for the sake of the eye.
Context: An example of final cause in biology

Quote: The state exists for the sake of the good life.
Context: The teleological purpose of the polis

Quote: The nature of a thing is its end.
Context: A concise statement of his teleology

Quote: We do not understand a thing until we have grasped its 'why,' that is to say, its cause.
Context: The importance of final cause for scientific understanding

Quote: The processes of nature are not random, but for a purpose.
Context: The core of Aristotelian natural philosophy

Quote: The relation of male to female is by nature a relation of superior to inferior and ruler to ruled.
Context: A foundational statement of his view on gender hierarchy

Quote: A woman is an unfinished man, left standing on a lower step in the scale of development.
Context: A metaphorical expression of his biological view

Quote: The female provides the material, the male provides the form and principle of movement for the generated entity.
Context: His theory of reproduction, assigning a passive role to the female

Quote: The deliberative faculty in a woman is without authority.
Context: On the supposed lack of full rational capacity in women

Quote: It is fitting for a woman to be a good housekeeper, and to keep what is brought into the house.
Context: Defining the domestic role of a wife

Quote: The courage of a man is shown in commanding.
Context: The masculine expression of the virtue of courage

Quote: A man is the origin of action, the begetter of change.
Context: Associating masculinity with agency and initiation

Quote: The virtue of a man is to be able to rule.
Context: Defining male virtue in terms of leadership

Quote: The man who is happy in solitude is either a beast or a god.
Context: Reiterating the social nature of man

Quote: The man of practical wisdom is the one who can deliberate well about what is good and advantageous for himself.
Context: The ideal of male rationality

Quote: The friend is another self.
Context: The famous definition of the friend

Quote: The desire for friendship comes quickly. Friendship does not.
Context: Distinguishing the initial impulse from the mature state

Quote: To perceive is to suffer.
Context: On the passive nature of sense perception, related to desire

Quote: The final cause, then, produces motion as being loved.
Context: The Unmoved Mover as the object of universal desire

Quote: The feeling of friendship is like the feeling of being at home.
Context: A psychological analogy for the comfort of love

Quote: The life of God is a life of perfect contemplation.
Context: The activity of the divine mind

Quote: God is thought thinking thought itself.
Context: The famous description of divine activity

Quote: The universe must be one and eternal, and the prime mover must be one and eternal.
Context: A cosmological argument for a single, eternal god

Quote: The divine is the first and highest principle.
Context: The foundational role of the divine in metaphysics

Quote: God is not a ruler in the sense of issuing commands, but as an end which moves by being loved.
Context: The non-providential, final-causal role of God

Quote: The virtues we get by first exercising them, as also happens in the case of the arts as well. For the things we have to learn before we can do them, we learn by doing them.
Context: On the acquisition of virtue through repeated action

Quote: The happy man both lives well and does well; for we practically define happiness as a sort of good life and good action.
Context: Connecting happiness to virtuous activity

Quote: The man who is without virtue cannot bear his good fortune in the right way.
Context: On the danger of prosperity without character

Quote: Virtue is a disposition, not a feeling or a capacity.
Context: Defining virtue as a settled state of character

Quote: The good man judges everything correctly; what things truly are, that they seem to him to be.
Context: The virtuous person perceives reality accurately

Quote: Happiness is an expression of the soul in considered actions.
Context: Happiness requires conscious, chosen activity

Quote: The many, the most vulgar, would seem to conceive the good and happiness as pleasure, and hence they also like the life of enjoyment.
Context: Critiquing hedonistic views of happiness

Quote: The life of the good man is good and pleasant in itself, for pleasure is a state of soul.
Context: The intrinsic pleasure of virtuous activity

Quote: If happiness is activity in accordance with virtue, it is reasonable that it should be in accordance with the highest virtue.
Context: Pointing toward contemplation as the highest happiness

Quote: The man who is truly good and wise will bear all kinds of fortune in a seemly way.
Context: On maintaining equanimity through life's changes

Quote: The city is the compound of households and villages in a perfect and self-sufficing life.
Context: Defining the political community

Quote: The law is a form of order, and good law must necessarily mean good order.
Context: The essential connection between law and social order

Quote: The best constitution is that which is based on the middle class.
Context: The political ideal of the mixed constitution

Quote: The state is a creation of nature, and man is by nature a political animal.
Context: The famous dictum on human political nature

Quote: The good citizen should know how to govern like a freeman and how to obey like a freeman.
Context: The dual capacity required of citizens

Quote: The investigation of the truth is in one way hard, in another easy.
Context: On the nature of philosophical inquiry

Quote: It is not necessary to have a beard to be a philosopher, but it is necessary to have a mind that can grasp the first principles.
Context: On the intellectual requirements for philosophy

Quote: The same statement can be both true and false, but not in the same respect.
Context: A principle of non-contradiction

Quote: We must begin by setting down the appearances, and then, after discussing the difficulties, go on to prove the reputable opinions about these experiences.
Context: The method of saving the appearances

Quote: It is the mark of an educated man to look for precision in each class of things just so far as the nature of the subject admits.
Context: On appropriate standards of exactness

Quote: The mathematical sciences particularly exhibit order, symmetry, and limitation; and these are the greatest forms of the beautiful.
Context: On the aesthetic dimension of science

Quote: The infinite is imperfect, unfinished, and unthinkable.
Context: On the concept of the infinite

Quote: Time is the number of motion in respect of before and after.
Context: His definition of time

Quote: A vacuum is impossible, because nature abhors a void.
Context: A principle of Aristotelian physics

Quote: The brain is an organ of minor importance, serving only to cool the blood.
Context: An erroneous physiological theory

Quote: Substance is that which is neither predicable of a subject nor present in a subject.
Context: The foundational definition of primary substance

Quote: The one and the many are opposed.
Context: A basic metaphysical distinction

Quote: The eternal is more real than the perishable.
Context: On the hierarchy of being

Quote: The nature of everything is its end.
Context: A teleological view of reality

Quote: The mind itself is thinkable just as the thinkable objects are.
Context: On the mind's capacity for self-awareness

Quote: The soul is the cause and principle of the living body.
Context: Defining the soul's relation to the body

Quote: The state of the soul is the source of our actions.
Context: On the soul as the origin of moral action

Quote: The irrational part of the soul can, in a manner, be persuaded by the rational.
Context: On the possibility of moral education

Quote: Sleep is a state of powerlessness of the perceptive faculty.
Context: A physiological and psychological observation

Quote: The memory is the persisting of the perceptive impression.
Context: His definition of memory

Quote: The best friend is he that wishes the best for the other for the other's sake.
Context: Defining the altruistic core of friendship

Quote: Friendship seems to consist more in giving than in receiving affection.
Context: On the active nature of loving

Quote: Equality is the soul of friendship.
Context: On the importance of parity in perfect friendship

Quote: Misfortune shows those who are not really friends.
Context: On how hardship reveals true friendship

Quote: The friendship of the good is good, and it increases with their meetings.
Context: On how virtuous friendship strengthens

Quote: The aim of the wise is not to secure pleasure, but to avoid pain.
Context: A goal of practical education

Quote: We must be taught to be good.
Context: Virtue is not innate but must be learned

Quote: To learn is a natural pleasure, not confined to philosophers, but common to all men.
Context: On the innate human enjoyment of learning

Quote: The most perfect political community must be one where the middle class is in control.
Context: Connecting political stability to education

Quote: The virtue of the rational part is to be found in teaching, not in being taught.
Context: On the active nature of intellectual virtues

Quote: The enthymeme is a rhetorical syllogism.
Context: On the primary tool of logical proof in rhetoric

Quote: The most important aspect of style is clarity.
Context: A fundamental principle of effective communication

Quote: To understand the emotions is to understand the human soul.
Context: On the deep connection between rhetoric and psychology

Quote: The role of the speaker is to see the available means of persuasion in each case.
Context: The core task of the orator

Quote: The hearer must be in a friendly mood toward the speaker.
Context: On the importance of audience disposition

Quote: The metaphor is the mark of genius.
Context: On the highest form of stylistic excellence

Quote: A likely impossibility is always preferable to an unconvincing possibility.
Context: A principle for constructing believable plots

Quote: The poet's function is to describe, not the thing that has happened, but the kind of thing that might happen.
Context: Reiterating the universal nature of poetry

Quote: The perfection of style is to be clear without being mean.
Context: On the ideal quality of poetic language

Quote: The surprise arising from peripeteia is the most powerful element of tragic plot.
Context: On the dramatic power of reversal

Quote: The forms of government which are based on the common interest are correct constitutions.
Context: Linking just rule to the common good

Quote: The state exists for the sake of a good life, and not for life only.
Context: The ultimate purpose of the just state

Quote: The end of law is the good of the community.
Context: The teleological purpose of law

Quote: The worst form of inequality is to try to make unequal things equal.
Context: A critique of misguided equality

Quote: The virtue of justice consists in moderation, as regulated by wisdom.
Context: Placing justice within the mean framework

Quote: The feeling of confidence is the opposite of fear.
Context: Defining confidence in relation to fear

Quote: The coward is one who is excessive in fear.
Context: Placing cowardice as a vice of excess

Quote: The brave man's actions are motivated by the noble, the rash man's by the desire for honor.
Context: Distinguishing true courage from imitation

Quote: Courage is the knowledge of what is truly to be feared.
Context: Connecting courage with practical wisdom

Quote: The man who is fearless in facing a noble death is truly brave.
Context: On the ultimate test of courage

Quote: Wealth is a tool for living well, not the end of life.
Context: Reiterating the instrumental nature of wealth

Quote: The best political community is formed by citizens of the middle class.
Context: On the economic basis of political stability

Quote: The use of money was invented to facilitate exchange.
Context: On the origin and purpose of currency

Quote: The unnatural form of wealth-getting is usury, which is most reasonably hated.
Context: His condemnation of lending at interest

Quote: The liberal man does not value wealth for its own sake.
Context: The attitude of the virtuous toward money

Quote: The best life is the life of the mean, the life of moderation.
Context: The mean as guiding principle for life

Quote: The vices respectively fall short of or exceed what is right in both passions and actions.
Context: Defining vice in relation to the mean

Quote: The mean state is in a sense an extreme, for it is the best and the peak of excellence.
Context: The mean is not mediocrity but perfection

Quote: The task of ethics is to determine the mean.
Context: The central project of his ethical theory

Quote: The mean is relative to us, not to the thing itself.
Context: The mean depends on person and situation

Quote: The actual is the end, and for its sake the potential is acquired.
Context: The priority of actuality in teleology

Quote: The good is that at which all things aim.
Context: The teleological starting point of ethics

Quote: The form of a thing is its purpose and its end.
Context: Connecting formal and final cause

Quote: The final cause is the best of all causes, for it is the cause of causes.
Context: Elevating the final cause

Quote: The city is prior in nature to the individual, for the whole must be prior to the part.
Context: The teleological priority of community

Quote: The virtue of a woman and a man is not the same; a man's virtue lies in commanding, a woman's in obeying.
Context: A direct statement on gendered virtue

Quote: A woman's body is softer than a man's, and her soul more susceptible to fear and compassion.
Context: A physiological and psychological generalization

Quote: The woman is like a fertile field, the man like the sower of the seed.
Context: An agricultural analogy for reproduction

Quote: The friendship between husband and wife is the same as that which exists between ruler and subject.
Context: Placing marital relations politically

Quote: Women should be seen, not heard.
Context: A summary of his view on female conduct

Quote: The magnanimous man is concerned with honors and dishonors.
Context: Describing the 'great-souled' man

Quote: The man who is his own master is free.
Context: On the ideal of self-governance

Quote: The man who is unable to live in society must be either a beast or a god.
Context: The famous dictum on human sociality

Quote: The man of perfect virtue is the measure of what is noble and just.
Context: The phronimos as ethical standard

Quote: The man who shuns and fears everything and stands up to nothing becomes a coward.
Context: The path to cowardice

Quote: The object of love is the beautiful.
Context: A simple definition of what attracts love

Quote: The greatest of all pleasures is the pleasure of love.
Context: Acknowledging the power of love's pleasure

Quote: The desire for the good is the object of all rational wish.
Context: Rational love aims at the good

Quote: The friend shares his friend's sorrow and his joy.
Context: On the emotional bond of love

Quote: The love of a mother is the most disinterested of all loves.
Context: An observation on maternal love

Quote: The activity of God is immortality, that is, eternal life.
Context: The divine life is eternal actuality

Quote: The principle and first of beings is immovable.
Context: The Unmoved Mover as foundation

Quote: The divine thought is the most excellent of things.
Context: The supreme value of divine intellect

Quote: God does not will the universe; the universe wills God.
Context: The universe is drawn toward God

Quote: The prime mover exists of necessity, and inasmuch as it exists by necessity, its mode of being is good.
Context: The necessary and good existence of God
